title.children: Don't blame Australia's lowest-paid workers if interest rates rise again

image.altText: Philip Lowe wearing glasses and a suit sits at a table and speaks.

image.altText: Business people walk outside the Reserve Bank of Australia.

title.children: Economists split on looming RBA interest rate decision as households and markets brace for possible rise

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Latitude Financial say they have compromised my personal info. I have never been with them. That's a concern. - Natty. Hi Natty — even if you haven't been a Latitude customer directly, you might have applied for a financial product with them years ago, before they were even known as Latitude Financial. Before the Latitude brand became a household name (and a feature on the back of the Richmond Tigers guernsey, if you're AFL inclined like myself), they were GE Money — and have quite the history, including as Coles and Myer-branded credit cards. I did a deep dive on Latitude's history back in April, which you can read below. Hopefully it sheds some light into why you might have been contacted (and sorry to hear you've been caught up in their cyber breach).
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: If you've been contacted by Latitude Financial, this might be why

featuredLink.title: Latitude Financial only has 3 million customers, so why did it have 14 million personal records on file?

children.content: Latitude Financial say they have compromised my personal info. I have never been with them. That's a concern.
- Natty
Hi Natty — even if you haven't been a Latitude customer directly, you might have applied for a financial product with them years ago, before they were even known as Latitude Financial.
Before the Latitude brand became a household name (and a feature on the back of the Richmond Tigers guernsey, if you're AFL inclined like myself), they were
GE Money
— and have quite the history, including as
Coles
and
Myer-branded credit cards
I did a deep dive on Latitude's history back in April, which you can read below.
Hopefully it sheds some light into why you might have been contacted (and sorry to hear you've been caught up in their cyber breach).

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australia's workplace relations watchdog says it's not good enough for mining giant BHP to underpay nearly 30,000 employees for 13 years. The company self-reported the underpayments — which date back to 2010 — last week. It has estimated correcting the issue will cost more than $400 million, with superannuation and interest. Fair Work Ombudsman, Sandra Parker, has told ABC Radio Perth it may well be an oversight, but is disappointed by the company's "negligence". "Our concern is how can there be an oversight and a mistake that runs for 13 years without there being negligence and neglect on the part of the company," she said. "BHP itself said it's not good enough — that's right, it's not good enough for any employer — let alone one of Australia's largest and most sophisticated employers to underpay their employees on such a large scale."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: BHP criticised for 13 years of 'negligence and neglect' by underpaying workers

featuredLink.title: Investigation into whether BHP underpayments due to 'neglect' launched by Fair Work Ombudsman

mining giant BHP to underpay nearly 30,000 employees
for 13 years.
The company self-reported the underpayments — which date back to 2010 — last week.
It has estimated correcting the issue will

, with superannuation and interest .
Fair Work Ombudsman,

, has told

it may well be an oversight, but is disappointed by the company's "negligence".
"Our concern is how can there be an oversight and a mistake that runs for 13 years without there being negligence and neglect on the part of the company," she said.

it's not good enough

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It's a lineball call with the cash rate decision this afternoon, but some economists believe the central bank will decide on another increase at its meeting. Markets are hinting at a pause, as is one survey by financial comparison website Finder, who surveyed 39 experts and economists. More than half of those surveyed believe the cash rate will hold at the current rate of 3.85%, but senior economics lecturer at the University of Melbourne, Tomasz Wozniak thinks the cash rate could go up by 0.15 percentage points. "The inflation is high and way above the RBA's targets," he said. "It increased monthly from 6.4 to 6.8% in May. Quarterly, in seasonally adjusted terms, that's still 7.3%, it's very high. "Prices in all groups of expenditures increased, especially in groceries and housing." Mr Wozniak said he'd be "surprised" if they didn't increase the cash rate. "That would be working probably against their statutory obligation to curb the inflation and keeping the GDP or the Australian economy in pretty good shape," he said.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What's the argument for a rate rise this afternoon?

children.content: It's a lineball call with the cash rate decision this afternoon, but some economists believe the central bank will decide on another increase at its meeting.
Markets are hinting at a pause, as is one survey by financial comparison website Finder, who surveyed 39 experts and economists.
More than half of those surveyed believe the
cash rate will hold
at the current rate of 3.85%, but senior economics lecturer at the University of Melbourne,
Tomasz Wozniak
thinks the cash rate could go up by
0.15 percentage points
"The inflation is high and way above the RBA's targets," he said.
"It increased monthly from 6.4 to 6.8% in May. Quarterly, in seasonally adjusted terms, that's still 7.3%, it's very high.
"Prices in all groups of expenditures increased, especially in groceries and housing."
Mr Wozniak said he'd be "surprised" if they didn't increase the cash rate.
"That would be working probably against their statutory obligation to curb the inflation and keeping the GDP or the Australian economy in pretty good shape," he said.
